titleStmt.title: Andalusian Culture and Custioms in Testour
TUNOCENT Dataset
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 31647

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

media.desc: The informant has not explicitly agreed to the publication of the audio recording. Thus, the audio recording is available only to the research project itself.

monogr.title: The Arabic Dialect of Testour (Northwestern Tunisia): A phonological and morphological analysis

biblStruct.note: The town of Testour lies close to the Medjerda river in northwestern Tunisia and it was founded in the 17th century by the Muslim Moriscan community who was exiled from Spain, after the Reconquista led to a rise in Christian zeal in the Iberian peninsula. By making North Africa their new home, the Moriscos introduced their customs, agriculture, architecture, food and dress amongst many other things, to these new towns and to the locals. The inhabitants of Testour today claim that they are the descendants of the Moriscos, and as such as keen to practice typical Moriscan trades, such as producing the chéchia hat and celebrating the Maʔlūf music. This master’s thesis aims at documenting some of the phonological and morphological features of the Arabic dialect of the present community of Testour, on which to my knowledge, no such linguistic works currently exists. The recordings on which this thesis is based have been collected during the framework of the TUNOCENT project hosted by the University of Vienna, which strives to collect and document the dialects of certain towns in northwestern and central Tunisia. The outcome of this thesis is to put Testour on the linguistic map of Tunisia, a country on which relatively very little has been done in this regard, as well as to hopefully contribute a better insight on the ambiguous dialectal classifications in Tunisia.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the TUNOCENT teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the arche prefix are pointers to resources archived in the long-term repository ARCHE.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to assets used by the TUNOCENT web application.
Private URIs using the datatypes.vicav.fl prefix are pointers to feature lists.
Private URIs using the datatypes.vicav.st prefix are pointers to VICAV sample texts.
Private URIs using the datatypes.tunocent.ums prefix are pointers to transcribed texts of unmonitored speech.
Private URIs using the datatypes.tunocent.pp prefix are pointers to TUNOCENT place profiles.

spanGrp.span: They left from, they were exiled from Spain
Do you know this story or not?
Well, in 1400, shall I tell you or not? In 1509
No, in 1490
You see, at the end of the 15th century, the Umayyad state in Spain was weakened.
When it was totally weakened, the Arabs were expelled from Spain, all of them left.
And what did they call them? At that time they used to call them Moriscos. Why? It’s because they were not pure Arabs, they were mixed
Some of them were married to Spanish, others were married to Arabs, they called them Moriscos.

When even the last one was expelled from Spain, they reached a point that when they found out that someone had a great-great grandfather who has Arab origins (an Arab ancestor from four generations before)
They would not let a person who has an Arab ancestor from four generations before stay (in Spain). What is the meaning of a great-great grandfather?
Do you know what a great-great grandfather is?
Yes, from four generations before, do you see?
When he (the grandfather from four generations ago) was an Arab, they would not let the person stay in Spain, they had to leave.
They forced them into exile and not even one person who had Arab ancestors going back four generations remained
They spread all over North Africa. Most of them went to Morocco
Few of them went to Algeria, not a lot, no, no, no, no, no. The nature of the Algerians was difficult, they did not manage to adapt to them
Do you understand me? Therefore, only a few went to Algeria.
The majority settled in Tunisia, in Tunisia. Since they used to live in cities, they were not able to live in the mountains
Not like the tribes here. They lived in the cities, and where were the cities? They had to always live close to the water
And where close to the water? At that time here in North Africa, we had, most of all, the Medjerda river, the Medjerda river is ours.
So, they started to live on the shores of Medjerda river.
The most important cities in which they lived were at the shores of Medjerda river, starting with Testour, Medjez (al-Bab) Tebourba, Qalat al-Andalus
Up until you reach its where it pours, you arrive in Nabeul, where the river pours into the sea, do you understand me?
Right! Do you see where all these villages are?
They met the people there, and they managed to adapt to them
And they imported with them their customs, for example the Baklava,
The Baklava has Moriscan origins.
No, it’s Syrian.
No sir! The origin of the Baklava is Moriscan, and no one can tell me otherwise. Do you know why?
When they expelled them, they baked the Baklava and hid their jewellery inside of it
They hid their rings inside of it, they hid their necklaces inside of it.
When someone would come to search them, they would say “When I am hungry what can I eat? I baked the Baklava and I will leave with it.”
However, inside of the Baklava they were hiding their gold.
The Baklava is of Moriscan origin, no one can disagree with me about this.
They brought here their customs, for example the architecture. For example, before they (the native Tunisians) did not use tiles.
From where did they get to know about the tiles? They got to know about this from the Moriscos. They introduced their architecture,
The introduced their language and they introduced music.
They are Arab.
They are Arab, however, they have other customs, not like us.
They brought their music, before we didn’t have music, it was considered forbidden to sing, as we say
When they came, music came along,and their vibes. And what's more they lived with...
They lived with...
They lived with...What is their names? What do they call them?
Those nomads, the Spanish nomads, what do they call them?
The ones like those that we have...
Gypsies
Gypsies!
They lived with them, and they had their music, music for them was essential, do you understand me?
Anyways, they also brought their cuisine, like the makrouth
And they brought many other pastries.
And what else?
